BC-AIRLINES-CHECKIN-1105(2TAKES)-NYT 
AIRLINES IN A PUSH FOR SHORTER LINES 

  
 (ATTN: N.J., Mich., Minn., Alaska, Ore.)   By DAVID LEONHARDT   
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service   

   A traveler prints a boarding pass and luggage tags from her
office computer, drives to the airport and walks straight past the
snaking line at the main counter. She drops her bags on a conveyer
belt and dashes to the gate, where the bar code on her boarding
pass causes her photograph to appear on the gate agent's computer
screen. Her entire time in the airport, from curb to gate: less
than 10 minutes.

   At the moment, this scenario is little more than a dream for all
but a few elite passengers. Airports are more crowded than ever,
and lines are much longer than they were even a few years ago.

   But in a competition to attract the business travelers who are
responsible for most of the carriers' revenue, major airlines are
spending tens of millions of dollars on new technology.

   They hope to whisk passengers through terminals more quickly,
redefining what industry executives glumly call ``the airport
experience.''

   By the end of the year, Continental Airlines plans to have 300
ATM-like computers across the United States that allow people to
print their own boarding passes and baggage tags. Delta Air Lines
has spent $750 million over the last two years wiring airports and
preparing to introduce similar gadgets. Northwest Airlines responds
to canceled flights at its hubs by rolling out banks of wireless
phones with direct connections to its reservations desk.

   And Alaska Airlines, the most aggressive recently in using
technology, allows people with electronic tickets to print boarding
passes from their home or office computers.

   As part of a pilot program, it has also scanned the driver's
licenses of about 500 frequent fliers into its computer system. The
bar code on the boarding pass retrieves both the driver's license
and a larger photo, so travelers never have to reach into their
wallets before boarding the plane.

   For now, business travelers are the main beneficiaries of the
improvements. Some of the initiatives, such as calling passengers'
cell phones to tell them about a late flight, are available only to
the top tier of frequent fliers, and others, like the kiosks,
appeal mainly to travelers who do not check bags.

   Continental has even installed a kiosk in the lobby of AT&T's
corporate headquarters in New Jersey, so travelers there can get
boarding passes before they arrive at the airport. And Northwest is
testing a program that allows employees of 10 Midwestern companies
to print their own passes off the airline's Web site.

   But unlike some other recent perks for corporate road warriors _
like expanded first-class sections or the installation of double
beds on overnight flights _ much of the new technology will
eventually be available for all passengers to use, industry experts
said.

   ``Airports weren't designed for the volumes they're now
getting,'' said Michael L. Zea, a vice president in Mercer
Management Consulting's airline practice. ``There's a lot of strain
on the system, and technology can be very helpful in easing that.''

   Of course, automated systems are not always reliable. During a
threatened strike by US Airways employees in March, passengers
holding electronic tickets needed old-fashioned paper tickets to
have any hope of getting a seat on another carrier. And if the
airlines eventually replace agents with the machines, they could
both anger their unions and force passengers to do more work in
order to board a plane, travel experts said.

   But after a year in which consumer complaints more than doubled
from their 1998 level, industry executives say that shortening the
lines at their airport counters is a sure-fire way to boost their
carriers' images.

   As air travel has surged during the long economic expansion, and
the size of airports and airline staffs has failed to keep up, the
average amount of time that travelers spend on line at the main
counter has reached 16 minutes, up 20 percent from three years ago,
according to Airport Interviewing and Research, a White Plains,
N.Y., company that surveys passengers.

   The stricter security standards that the government has adopted
in recent years have added to the lines, as well.

   As a result, no matter what travelers think of folding
themselves into a middle seat or drinking the airlines' mediocre
coffee, they will generally be happy if their trips take less time
than they have come to expect, airline executives say. ``You can
make up for a lot of coffee sins by having a line that's been
reduced,'' said Dirk C. McMahon, the senior vice president for
ground operations at Northwest Airlines. And at $10,000 apiece, the
machines cost much less than additional employees.

   The stakes are high enough to have led to two recent lawsuits
between airlines with different views about how best to move
passengers through airports. Continental has sued both Delta and
United to force them to remove metal templates on baggage X-ray
machines that prevent passengers, including Continental's, from
carrying large bags onto airplanes.

   Continental says that its planes' overhead compartments are
large enough to hold the bags and that allowing customers to carry
on luggage instead of checking it reduces delays. Delta and United
say the big bags result in overstuffed bins that cause delays.

   Though it is unclear which argument holds the most sway with
passengers, they clearly care deeply about the issue. Bill Harsh, a
management consultant who flies over 200,000 miles a year, said he
has stopped flying United, once his main carrier, because he could
no longer carry on his luggage.

   ``I had a bag that fit in every overhead compartment in America
but did not fit through their template,'' said Harsh, who lives in
a Maryland suburb of Washington.

   A spokeswoman for United said the airline has received few
complaints about the templates.

   For now, though, the biggest attempts to reduce lines involve
technology. Delta and other carriers are putting up computer
screens near gate counters in an attempt to answer easy questions,
such as the reason for a delay, that often clog lines. Northwest's
agents in Detroit and Minneapolis are using hand-held computers to
print boarding passes for passengers waiting in long lines.

   The initiative that is the furthest along is the installation of
the ticket kiosks that print boarding passes. Alaska, Continental
and Northwest have put them in dozens of airports across the
country, and British Airways and Alitalia, among others, use them
in Europe. Delta has installed them in Boston, New York and
Washington for shuttle flights, and United is now testing a version
in Aspen, Colo.

   nn

   Airline executives say they have not cut any jobs because of the
machines but probably would have had to hire more new agents
without the kiosks.

   Typically about 6 feet tall, the machines allow passengers with
electronic tickets to insert a credit card, print a boarding pass
and sometimes change their seats or get a ticket on an earlier
flight. The machines pose, in text form, the security questions
that gate agents ask passengers who check in in the old-fashioned
way.

   For now, there is rarely a line, and almost never a long one, at
the kiosks. Mary Anne Smith of Metuchen, N.J., used one of them
last week at Newark International Airport before boarding a
Continental flight on a business trip. ``They're quicker even than
when there are no lines'' at the counters, she said. ``I don't have
to talk to anyone.''

   They are mainly useful, however, for passengers who have no bags
to check and no questions to ask a gate agent.

   Only Alaska Airlines, in Anchorage, Alaska, and Portland, Ore.,
now permits passengers to print their own tags and then drop them
onto a conveyer belt from which the luggage is X-rayed and put on
the plane. The other carriers make passengers using the kiosks wait
in a line _ usually separate from the main one and shorter _ to
check their bags.

   The airlines have also not fully explained the policies to
travelers, analysts said. Smith, for example, said she believed she
could not have used the kiosk at all if she had wanted to check a
bag.

   In addition, the kiosks do not yet give fliers the same control
that talking to an agent does, particularly for frequent travelers
whose requests the airlines often meet, noted Samuel C. Buttrick,
an airline analyst at PaineWebber. ``I can't ask that the seat next
to me be left open. I can't ask about upgrade wait lists. I can't
ask questions about the status of a connecting flight,'' Buttrick
said, adding that he rarely uses the kiosks.
